sp.p: Look you here are two Letters; one to Mrs. Counterfeit, and another to Mr. Turnabout.—Follow me, and you ſhall receive further directions.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: And mine too.—Now I hope to ſee ſome miſchief.
sp.stage: Enter Politico and Lord Brittan, talking earneſtly.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I wonder your Lordſhip ſhould inſiſt ſo much upon Numbers, as if there were any ſtrength in divided and unarmed Numbers: can uncemented Sand grow into a Wall? or would your Lordſhip fear your Enemy, when you had his Sword in your own hand?

sp.speaker: L. Brit.
sp.p: Your Reverence miſtakes me—I am as great a ſtranger to fear as your ſelf; but ſtill I do not love to extinguiſh all rational apprehenſions of danger: Divided numbers are not of the ſtrength that united are, where the quantity is equal; but you do not well conclude from thence, That they are of no ſtrength at all: There are Mountains of divided Sand, that can reſiſt the ſtroke of a Cannon, and overwhelm the beſt diſciplin'd Troop in Europe: And tho I ſhould not fear a ſingle Enemy, if I had his Sword in my hand; yet I ſhould think my ſelf in an ill condition, if I were aſſaulted by two or three hundred naked men of equal ſtrength and courage with my ſelf.—This is our caſe;—We have 200 to one againſt us, and that ſeems to me to out-ballance all other Advantages—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: That is becauſe your Lordſhip has not conſidered the Policy of foreign Courts, as I have done. What vaſt numbers do they keep in Slavery, grievous inſupportable Slavery, by little or no force at all!—

sp.speaker: L. Britt.
sp.p: That is, becauſe the People love to keep themſelves ſo, which our Countreymen do not: Whether they are born Slaves by ſome peculiar Influence of the Heavens, or whether Cuſtom has made that Yoke to be eaſie, or whether that ſervile diſpoſition is deriv'd from Father to Son, by ſome unperceivable manner of Tradition;—the Cauſe is uncertain, but the Effect is plain.—But to think Engliſh-men to be eaſily kept in ſubjection, becauſe foreigners can, is as good Logick, as to conclude a Lion dares not fight, becauſe a Sheep is a timorous Creature.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I perceive your Lordſhip is not skill'd in the Politicks; I can give you ſeveral reaſons why there is no danger in the dreaded number of the Hereticks: For firſt, they want an Head; and what, alas! is Body without an Head? There's one for you.

sp.speaker: L. Britt.
sp.p: Your Argument is Metaphorical, but not concluſive.—It is true, theſe popular Inſurrections that are rais'd by the Power or Intereſt of one particular Man, are ſoon quell'd, when the Head is once remov'd; for the Cauſe taken away, the Effect ceaſes. But where the cauſe of diſcontent is general, an Head is never wanting, for many hands make light work.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p:
Then again'—The Hereticks want Councel and Conduct: Alas! all their Great Men are bred in the Engliſh Court, and know nothing of the French and Italian Fineſſes: There are no men in the world, excepting thoſe of my Order, that underſtand the true Methods and Principles of
Government. Alas! your Engliſh Lords are troubled with ſcruples of Conſcience, and pretend to tenderneſs and good nature, and think themſelves always oblig'd to ſtick to the immutable Rules of Honour; and talk of Juſt and Unjuſt, and I know not what whimſeys: They don't conſider, that it is impoſſible for a States-man to accompliſh any great Deſigns, that boggles at any ſort of means that are conducing to his End, tho never ſo unjuſt and cruel.—

sp.speaker: L. Britt.
sp.p: I wiſh you do not find thoſe Lords, which you ſo much deſpiſe, to be Maſters of more Policy than is conſiſtent with the good of the Catholick Cauſe.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Pſhaw! Pſhaw! never fear it.—When all's done, we have an Army to defend us.

sp.speaker: L. Britt.
sp.p: An Army ſympathizes with the major part of the Nation out of which they are taken; and what raiſes Jealouſies in the One, is ſure to raiſe Diſcontents in the Other.—Heaven ſend we may never ſtand in need of that.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Pſhaw! pſhaw! your Lordſhip is too timorous.

sp.speaker: L. Britt.
sp.p: No man, but what's defended by a Gown, dares tell me ſo.—Once more, farewell. And when you ſee all England in a flame, your ſelves purſued to the water-ſide, and offering all your Treaſure for a Boat; when Catholicks are driven from their Houſes, and made the Object of a publick ſcorn, remember then I had no hand in this.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: And when you ſee the Triumphs of our Cauſe, all bending low unto the See of Rome, the Hereticks or forced to comply, or roving up and down the world for Bread, but finding none: when this you live to ſee, remember well that mine is the contrivance; 'tis I propos'd the End, and found the Means; ſhap'd the Tools, and perfected the Work; and mine's the Honour.—

sp.speaker: L. Britt.
sp.p: May it be ſo.—I leave the Honour and the Danger unto you.—Farewell, I've done my beſt.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Well, this Lord is honeſt, but Maſter of extreme wrong Notions in Policy, as if he had been bred under ſome Calviniſtical Pedant, that never read Machiavel.—But I muſt now lay aſide thoughts of State-affairs, and mind the grand Concerns of ſofter Love. Leucaſia's eyes have ſhot a fire into my breaſt, which nothing but her ſelf can extinguiſh: If I can enjoy her in the perſon of a diſcarded Officer, I ſhall look upon it as my greateſt fineſs.—For as there is greater art in making a Chain for a Flea than an Elephant, ſo there is ſomething more skill in ſubduing the heart of a Woman, than in ſubverting a Kingdom.
O Mrs. Counterfeit, you're welcome, moſt heartily welcome.—What news?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: O, the moſt obliging News in the World.—Leucaſia is yours, your Plots take to admiration.—I vow you don't act fairly, to outwit a Woman in her own Profeſſion.—Read this
sp.stage: Gives him a Letter he reads.

body.p: The account you give of that Noble Perſon, and his ſuffering in ſo good a Cauſe, will not permit me to be cruel.—I honour ſuch Noble Patriots; and if it is his deſire to make known to me any part of his grievances, he ſhall find an honourable and kind reception from

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Why, look you, Mrs. Counterfeit, did not I tell you that nothing could reſiſt my Policy? Here's a Lady that hates our Religion, and in particular my Order and Perſon: Now who but my ſelf could extract good out of ſo much evil, and make her averſion a ſtep to enjoy her?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: If you are as quick in Execution, as fine in Projection, that will ſoon be done. Or if you ſhould be put to the trouble to raviſh, or ſo, if opportunity favours, your diſguiſe is your ſecurity.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: There thou hitt'ſt the Nail on the head: my diſguiſe is ready, you ſhall go in and ſee it fitted.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I wait your Commands; but you muſt go incognito, without any Equipage.—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Pray, Mrs. Counterfeit, leave the contriving part to me, I think I am Maſter of that.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: And you muſt be ſure to aggravate the Ingratitude of Prieſts and Jeſuits.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: What ſtill moving beyond your ſtation? muſt the Spring riſe higher than the Fountain-head? have you not learn'd all this from me? and do you pretend to teach?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No, indeed, I have not learn'd all from you; my Mother, and my good Grandmother, and my Aunt, and my great Aunt, taught me a great deal, and I have had 50 years experience; ſo that you might truſt a little to my Judgment.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Then you will pretend to direct me?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No, an't pleaſe your Reverence, I will not pretend to that: You do excel me and all mankind in the myſterious arts of Love; I muſt moſt humbly acknowledge it to be ſo.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Then follow me; and remember the contriving part is mine; the executive we muſt ſhare between us.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: You ſee how far I have condeſcended to cure your capricious humour; tho I muſt confeſs your carriage to me, and your hair-brain'd Jealouſie, does deſerve my ſcorn, or rather is below it.—

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: I confeſs my error, and am ready to redeem your loſt favour with my Sword. What is it you will command?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: A certain pretended Lord is pleas'd to think me a very fit perſon to be his Whore. Now what would you do in vindication of my Honour?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Oh very little.—Perhaps I might only cut his Throat, or whip him through the Lungs or ſome ſuch trifle:—Neither more nor leſs—

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: No, that's too much.—But I ſuppoſe that if he ſhould refuſe to draw, you would grudge him the pains to kick him, or aſſiſt my Servants in toſſing him in a Blanket.—

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: No, by heavens I would not. Good Madam, tell me, When, where, and how I ſhall ſerve you, you ſhall ſee with what zeal I'll do it.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: You muſt retire immediately into this Cloſet, and not ſtir till the Signal be given. This is the leaſt Penance I can impoſe for your Jealouſie, and other high miſdemeanors; and I ſuppoſe herein I am not ſo rigid as the Fathers.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Fy! Fy! Good Madam, tell me no more of the Fathers, they are meer Babies and Children: I care no more for the Fathers, than I do for the Indian Bramines, or Turkiſh Mufti, unleſs it be for my own ends; for tho that Beldame Counterfeit was pleas'd to give your Ladiſhip an account that they intended to fool me, yet I can aſſure you I find as great encouragement as any New Convert of 'em all.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: I will tell thy true Character: Thy Love makes thee greedy of Eſtate and Honour, and the greedineſs of Eſtate and Honour make thee love ſo much the more eagerly; now to cure this vicious circulation of humours, I will firſt make thee weary of poaching after the Fathers, by rendring thee odious to them; and then, as for Love, you know the laſt remedy for that.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Phu! phu! Politico is ſo much my Friend, thou canſt never render me odious to him.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Yes, I will, in the ſpace of half an hour.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: 'Tis not an Age and a half can do it. Will you venture your Maidenhead upon that Bett?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Yes, I wou'd, if you had one to ſtake againſt it.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Prethee what doſt talk of one, I have had an hundred in my time.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Ay, but they are now all vaniſh'd, and become as inviſible as your 20 Mannors.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: That's true indeed. But to be ſerious; if you have a mind to convert me, you may find a nearer way; it is but taking me to your ſelf for ever, and then I will ſoon bid adieu to all the Gang of pedantical Fathers.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: But my reſolution is to make thee weary of that Society, without making uſe of that dangerous Matrimonial Remedy. And if I do it not, then ſay my wit has fail'd me.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: And if you do redeem me from that Gang without paying your ſelf for my Ranſom, then ſay that I am not Maſter of Wit, Reſolution, Common Senſe, or Reaſon.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Madam, here's a Perſon of Quality at the door in a Coach.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: That's the man, bid him come up.—Now, Mr. Turnabout, if you mean ever to purchaſe my Love by uſing him very ſcurvily, retire into the next Room, and ſtir not unleſs he offer force, or I give the ſignal.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Let me alone for that.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Now this fool Politico will think that I don't know him in his diſguiſe; but heaven be prais'd I am ready for his reception.
sp.stage: Enter Politico in a very rich Commander's Habit.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Madam, I'm come to throw my ſelf at your feet for pardon.—I preſume Mrs. Counterfeit has acquainted you with my Perſon and Character.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: My Lord, if your intentions are not criminal, it is ſuperfluous to ask a Pardon. Beſides, the Character I received of your Perſon, and the account of your Sufferings in ſo good a Cauſe, place you above all formalities of that nature. I have rather reaſon to admire at your Lordſhip's condeſcenſion to one ſo much your Inferior in Quality and Honour.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I muſt confeſs, none ever ſerved the Proteſtant Cauſe with greater Zeal and Integrity; and this drew upon me the envy of Politico, Bigot, and others, which occaſion'd my removal from Court; but ſtill my very Ruins are above the pity of the very beſt of them, and it lies in your Ladiſhips Power to build up the higheſt degree of human felicity.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: My Lord, I can never enough reflect upon the baſeneſs and ingratitude of thoſe Prieſts towards your Lordſhip and other worthy Patriots: but I am fill'd with horror and amazement, that a Perſon of your Worth, Courage, Conduct and Fidelity, ſhould be undermin'd by ſuch a raskally Crew of fantaſtical Prieſts as Politico, Bigot, Cautious, and Mackdonnel! a Gang of whimſical, nonſenſical Blockheads, that look as odly in the Court, as a Skull in the Preſence-Chamber; whoſe whole skill lies in Books, and that too no farther than Title-pages; and perhaps, if ſome ſpecial Roguery does require it, they may proceed to the Index, and ſo begin that, as they do all other things, at the wrong end. And—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Nay, good Lady, proceed no farther; I forgive my Enemies; and you know my buſineſs here is Love, and not Revenge.—Now muſt I hear my ſelf rail'd at, and ſay nothing.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: My Lord, I cannot but admire your Generoſity in forgiving your Enemies; but I will take the liberty to tell you, that They, and eſpecially Politico, are of all things my averſion.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: But yet, I hope, you will grant that Politico is the very beſt, the top and flower of them all.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: I vow, my Lord, I am of a quite contrary Opinion; for firſt, as to his perſon—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Nay, good Lady, let his Perſon alone, it will never hurt you.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: I will aſſure you, the remembrance of his Perſon does hurt me this very moment, it was ſuch a filthy ſpectacle, Spits.—His Meen and Air ſo affectedly odd and boyiſh; his Eyes Luſtful, and, if I may ſay it, Goatiſh; his Hands clumſie; his Head lumpiſh; nothing good but his Voice, which did a little reſemble with your Lordſhips, and make an attonement for his other Enormities.—Sure this will ſting him.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Come, Madam, be not ſo Satyrical upon the famous Politico, tho my Enemy: the Habit of an Order does oftentimes diſfigure a moſt excellent Shape and Meen: but be that what it will, you muſt needs grant Politico to be the greateſt States-man in the World, and a man of the fineſt Contrivance in Europe.—All his Enemies confeſs him to be a wiſe man.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p:
I know he eſteems himſelf ſo, but the world has a different Opinion of him. Would a wiſe man throw off ſuch a worthy gallant Gentleman as your ſelf, that are ſteddy by a Principle of Duty, to make room for mercenary Slaves, that know no higher Equity than Intereſt? Would a wiſe man encourage Lying, Diſſimulation and Hypocriſy
in others, when he knows not how ſoon they may make uſe of the ſame Arts to his own Diſtruction? Would a wiſe Man puniſh or deride others for their Conſtancy, Loyalty, and Fidelity, to ſecure a Government which needs muſt periſh without them? Do you think, I ſay, my Lord, all this to be the part of a wiſe Man?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Good Lady talk no more of Politico, my buſineſs is Love.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: And how can I more effectually expreſs my Love to your Perſon and Merits, than by railing at thoſe Enemies of yours, that have caſt ſuch a Cloud upon them? Good, my Lord, join with me in a few innocent Curſes againſt Father Politico, and all his Gang, that have done you this inſupportable Injury.—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, excuſe me from Curſing; I came hither for the bleſſing of your Love, and muſt my ſelf be curs'd without it.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: No excuſes, my Lord, it will leſſen the Opinion I have of the greatneſs of your Spirit. Come, you ſhall invent ſome new Curſes with me.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: My mind now is ſo full of Love, that I can invent nothing that has the leaſt reliſh of hatred. Dear Madam, excuſe me.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Then, if you will not invent, you ſhall leave that to me, and only conclude with an hearty Amen.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I wonder that your Ladiſhip will offer to impoſe upon me the Office of a Pariſh-Clerk. How ſhall I be able to give a tuneable Accent to Amen?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip is modeſt.—I know you have an excellent Baſe, and can't chuſe but do it very well.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: What an unconſcionable Woman is this, to expect that I ſhould curſe my ſelf, and my Brethren.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: I'll ſhew you the way; a little curſing will make you reliſh the ſweetneſs of Love the better.—May they be always contriving, and never bring any thing to effect. May they employ none but Knaves and Fools, and may thoſe at laſt deceive them; may they heap up vaſt Treaſures, and Porters enjoy them; may they fall into an immoderate love of themſelves, and into hatred of all Mankind beſides; and if ever any of them have a Miſtriſs, may ſhe be Beautiful, Rich, Virtuous, and Heretical, and that will be plague enough.—Good my Lord ſay, Amen.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Indeed, Madam, I have a Cold, I can't do it with a Grace.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter for Grace, do but ſpeak it heartily.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: May all their Plots be too improbable to take effect, and not improbable enough to pleaſe as a Fiction in a Romance or Novel. But may they have the happineſs to partake of that vicious Mediocrity, which is good for juſt nothing.—You muſt ſay, Amen.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Well, I perceive your ſuperabounding Goodneſs, does make you pronounce Amen very faintly.—I will therefore deſiſt from Curſing; and I have Ten thouſand more to utter, and none of them undeſerv'd.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: A pox of this Amour, I am weary of it. Aſide.—Madam, if you would curſe my Enemies, the beſt way is to make me happy with your Love.—It will burſt their hearts with envy.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: If I had any happineſs to confer, your requeſt would be reaſonable; but I fear you are come out of one misfortune, with intention to fall into a greater. Matrimony, if that be your deſign, cures no Diſtempers of the Mind, but by inflicting greater. It is a corroſive, that may deaden the Fleſh in order to Amputation, but it ſeldom effects a Cure that is better than the Diſeaſe.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Tho Matrimony cannot, there is ſomething in your Ladiſhips power that can. Madam, I am a Soldier, and you know Men of our Profeſſion flie more directly to enjoyment than others do, over all thoſe Forms and Obſtacles invented by Fools and Platonick Lovers.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Then I perceive at length your Lordſhips meaning; you came hither inſtead of telling your Sufferings, with a deſign to Whore me.—Pray, my Lord, ſpeak plainly, did you come hither with a deſign to Whore me?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Madam, you preſent the moſt pleaſant thing in the World, in the moſt hideous Dreſs. Give it a ſofter Name, and the buſineſs is half done.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Whilſt I thought you Virtuous, and a Sufferer for your Countries Honour, I muſt confeſs, I had a profound reſpect for your Perſon; but now—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Ay, now you may boaſt, that you have conquered him whom Sovereign Princes could not.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: When Luſt has turn'd a Man into a Beaſt, there can be no great triumph in ſuch a Conqueſt.—Mrs. Counterfeit, is as much miſtaken in her little Policies, as Father Politico in his great ones.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Theſe ſtrugglings of Modeſty, choak all true Pleaſure in the Birth: It is more generous to yield without previous Hypocriſy.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: I am not us'd to Diſcourſes, of this nature; adieu.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, we muſt not part ſo.
sp.stage: Steps to the Door, and locks it.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Then you intend Violence.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Ay, but the moſt raviſhing,—that ever was experienc'd by Woman.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Sure you will not put me to the trouble to call my Servants to my aid.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: It is in vain; they are as ſecure as your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Sure you are not ſo much a Villain!

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: If I am not, you need not fear me. The next Room, Madam, is a more pleaſant ſcene for Love.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Sure Turnabout will not fail me now,—if he does I'm undone— aſide—She knocks.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: 'Tis all in vain.
sp.stage: He offers to carry her out.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: What means this noiſe? Villain unhand the Lady.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: What, my Rival Turnabout!—I'm undone.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: How dare you offer violence to a Lady in her own Lodgings?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: You call that Violence which was only a little innocent freedom.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: You ſeem to be a Man of Quality, and a Soldier, you have begun an Injury like a Villain, and muſt defend it like a Man,—Draw.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: What ſhall I do now? I know no more how to Fight than a Girl of Fifteen, that is only skilled in the Innocent uſe of her Nails.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Come, Sir, ſtand not amazed; Draw, or you're a Dead Man.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I am not afraid to Draw, nor unable to chaſtife your ſawcy intruſion—But I hope you will not force me to that rudeneſs in a Ladies Apartment, whoſe Honour you pretend to maintain.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: You were not afraid of a greater rudeneſs than this, and therefore have no reaſon to ſcruple a leſs: Sir, I ſay—Draw.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: All the words in the World ſhall not make me tranſgreſs the Rules of Decency and Order.—

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Then ſhall this do it; kicks him. Or this, again.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: No, Sir, I have more breeding than to incur an abſurdity of ſo high a nature,—But you ſhall repent of this; Politico is my Friend,—you know his Power.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Damn Politico—Do you wear a Sword, and ſhelter your ſelf under the Protection of a whimſical Gownman?—Draw, or I have another expedient for you.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: If I Draw, I am certainly kill'd, and Ten thouſand of the beſt Plots in the World are moſt certainly ſpoil'd.—I muſt owe protection to Non-reſiſtance, and Paſſive-obedience.
I will not Draw—for I ſaid I would not.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Then I'le try another experiment on you: I have an Engine ſhall toſs you higher than a flying Chariot in Bartholomew-Fair.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Your pleaſure, Sir?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Four of you bring in a Blanket with all Expedition.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Well, Politico will revenge this injury.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: I tell thee again, Politico's an Aſs and a Fool; I my ſelf have made him a Fool this two months.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Bravely done my Lads—Let's carry that Raſcal into the Hall, and mount him.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Do you know who I am? Have a care what you do.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: I know thee to be a Coward; I believe thou art a Villain: and I vilely ſuſpect thou haſt ſomething in thee of the Fool, and that's enough for my purpoſe. To Foot. Carry him away.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: You will repent of it—Oh! Murther, Murther.
sp.stage: They carry him off by Force.
Enter Leucaſia, Betty, Sir Geo. Bigot, Cautious and Mackdonnel.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I ſent for you hither, to make known the ſhame of the fam'd Politico, who came hither in diſguiſe to rob me of my Honour; and I hope I have given you ſuch ocular demonſtration, as has left no room for doubt.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Thou art a brave Girl, I faith, I love revenge and miſchief when it is to the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.p: Yeſh by my ſhoul, and I do love miſchief wid all my heart, when dere is no hearme in in it.

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: It cannot be that Politico ſhould be guilty of ſuch a crime, who has labour'd ſo abundantly in the propagation of the Catholick Cauſe; It muſt be the deluſion of ſome evil ſpirit, that has put on the ſhape and habit of Politico, to bring this diſgrace on our Cauſe and Order: Let me come near him with my Exorciſms, and I will make him confeſs as much.—

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: If he ſhould confeſs himſelf a Devil, he would confeſs the truth.—

sp.speaker: Sir Geo
sp.p: Superſtition is incurable; and blind Zeal does ſeldom recover its ſight:—Has not my Neece ſhewed you the Jewels ſent by his own Hand?

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: A good Man may ſometimes be taken in a fault; but to be ſo very prodigal, as to give away Jewels of that value, is a wickedneſs that I think to be unpardonable.—

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: Come Brother, let's go and comfort Politico under this diſgrace.

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: Ay, that's better than to ſtay here, to become ſpectators of our own—Beſides I've Money to receive.

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: Farewell, and remember none ever provok'd our Order unreveng'd.

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: And don't think the World will believe this ſcandal; for we will ſwear it is falſe.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.p: Yeſh, it iſh falſh, very falſh.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: What is falſe?

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.p: What is falſh,—by my ſhoul I've forgat vat iſh dat vas falſh; but I'm ſure it vas ſometing.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: Come let's repair to Politico, it is vain to ſtay here.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Now, Madam, I hope my buſineſs is quite done, I've gain'd my own ends by Politico, who ſeems to be all melted into Love with my charming converſation; and I've helped your Ladiſhip in diſtreſs, which gives me ſome pretenſions unto your favour.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: It is natural for Men to err, and I perceive you are not altogether free from that human frailty; you build much upon your friendſhip with Politico, which is now at an end; you muſt expect nothing from him but Revenge and Malice; for he is the very perſon in diſguiſe, whom you have ſo plentifully kick'd and toſs'd in a Blanket.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: A Pox on't, 'tis impoſſible!

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Good Mr. Turnabout, ſpeak not impertinently, I do know it is ſo.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: 'Ounds this is a Trick I never thought on.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Since you doubt, follow me, and I'le ſoon convince you.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: I'le wait on you—but I am all amazement.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: And I will go and try one Plot, as old as I am. Here Jack,

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Go immediately to Kenſington, and turn my Horſe looſe with Bridle and Saddle, raiſe a report that I am miſſing, and, as you believe, Murthered; and to be ſure, you Dog, be ſecret: Or—

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, How ſhall I tell ſuch a Lie! I never told a Lie in my Life, an't pleaſe your Honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: You Dog, you can tell nothing elſe. Do it, or I'll cut your Throat.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Since your Honour will have it ſo, I'll try.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: By this device I hope to underſtand how far my Son is infected with Jeſuitical Principles—For if he is far gone, I ſhall diſcard him for ever.
Youth quickly learns the Vices of the Town, Swiftly they come and ſwiftly paſs away; But crimes infus'd by the more ſober Gown, Are much more black, and make a longer ſtay.

div.head: ACT V.
div.stage: The Scene changes to Politico's Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: ARe ye ſure then Leucaſia knew me?

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: She call'd us to be ſpectators of your ſhame.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Was ever man thus baffled in Amour, by the ſole malignity of Fortune?—for you muſt needs grant that the Plot was well laid.

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: Be not dejected, this Blanketting is a lively repreſentation of Great mens Fortunes, ſometimes up and ſometimes down; There is never any great Exaltation, but there is danger of a ſudden Depreſſion; this you knew before to be true by Speculation, and now receive a confirmation from palpable Experience.

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: Ay, but to be kick'd up and down like a Football, that was rude.

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: The Poets and Philoſophers compare the Life of Man to a Game at Tennis, The World is the Tennis-court, and men are the Balls which the Fates toſs up and down with Rackets: But great men, like great Footballs, are kicked up and down with greater violence. The ſtock was rude, but the emblem is good and uſeful.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Alas, I don't value a little Blanketing, or Kicking; But to have a Plot diſappointed—that grieves me.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.p: By my ſhoul, my dear Joy, de diſhappointment iſh not ſo great; for tho thow didſt not get into the Lady's Bed, thou didſt get poſſeſſion of the Blanket, and that is ſomething. Ha, ha.—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: And do you think that Turnabout knew me?

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: Not then,—but now I preſume he does.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Then will I be reveng'd on him.

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: But how?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: By giving him good words, raiſing his hopes, making him ſpend the remainder of his ſmall fortune in expectation of great things; and then doing for him juſt nothing at all.—And then for Leucaſia.—

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: Ay, prethee what canſt contrive againſt that peſtilent Heretick.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I have one of the fineſt Plots in the World, if thou wilt but aſſiſt me.

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: To be reveng'd on Leucaſia, is to do good to the publick; and I will refuſe no labour to accompliſh that.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Then this it is,—You hear the Rabble are in ſome violent commotions againſt the Men of our Perſuaſion and Order?

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: So great, that I have hid all my Trunks in your dark Cellar.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: You, Bigot, ſhall put on a Porters Frock, and excite them to all manner of Indignities.—

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: Againſt whom?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Againſt all Romaniſts, and eſpecially againſt my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: And what then?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Why, I will repair, under pretence of ſhelter, to Leucaſia's Lodgings—And there will ſcatter Books and Pictures that are peculiar to our way; then you ſhall bring down the Rabble to ſearch for me, preciſely at Nine of the Clock; I will be gone before that time, and ſo you with your wonted Eloquence, ſhall make the whole ſtorm light upon Leucaſia.

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: Brother, you muſt excuſe me, it is not for the good of the Cauſe.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Brother, you are miſtaken; I can demonſtrate it to be the ſureſt and ſecureſt way to promote it.

sp.speaker: Big
sp.p: You are the Oracle of Policy, I will go about it preſently: But let your Servant help me to a diſguiſe.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: 'Tis ready for you.

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: Adieu.
sp.stage: Enter Sir George Subtleman in the Habit of an Hermit, with a Beard down to his Waſte, followed by an Indian Boy.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.p: Hey day! By my ſhoul here iſh Shaint Pautrick come to ſhee us.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Salvete fratres venerandi, Pray which of you bears the venerable name of Politico?

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: Tu quoque ſalvus ſis venerande Pater, This is the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Is this the famous Politico, whoſe Fame is ſpread through all the habitable part of the World!—Is this the Wiſe, the Learned, the Divine Politico!

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I am that Politico of whom the World is pleaſed undeſervedly to ſpeak very great things, and far above my merits. A little feigned modeſty does well.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Then bleſſed are theſe eyes that ſee the Man. And bleſt theſe ears of mine that hear him ſpeak. And bleſt theſe Legs and Feet that brought me hither. My Vow is now perform'd, I'll ſhave my Beard, and live at reſt: But firſt, I muſt have leave to kiſs the Hem of your Garment.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: By no means—That's too much!

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Hinder me not Kiſſes his Coat. Bleſs me, what Virtue flows into my Body and mind from hence! Well, now I am happy.

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: This old fellow is ſo very condeſcending, that I fear he comes a begging.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Pray reverend Father tell us the reaſon of your tranſport, and whence you come.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Theſe Fourſcore years America has been my conſtant place of Prayers and Reſidence; And had been ſo till now, but that the fame of your great deeds has drawn me from my ſo far diſtant Cell, to ſee a perſon that the World adores.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I perceive by this, that I am very famous in America.

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: If you come from America, Father, I preſume you bring good ſtore of Gold.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Gold I deſpiſe; I came to learn and ſee the Wiſdom of this Man.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: But how came you to hear ſo much of my fame in America?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: How ſhould I hear that the Sun ſhines, or that the Stars bedeck the Canopy of Heaven?—You are known as much as they, and equally admired.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: That's much at ſo great a diſtance!—

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: What is more ſwift than Fame? There's not a Nurſe, but prays her tender off-ſpring may attain the Wiſdom of Politico—Not a Father that gives his bleſſing, but uſes this, Love—May thine be great as Politico's.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: 'Tis wandrous ſtrange!

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: They build Churches to your Name, and have an Holyday, that they honour your Wiſdom with, and is call'd, O Sapientia.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: All this may be true; But yet to prevent all ſcruples, I deſire you to ſhew ſome Letters Teſtimonial from the Provincial of our Order there, or other perſons.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Am I ſuſpected then?

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: Be not angry, Reverend Sir, you are not ſuſpected; but his Reverence muſt keep cloſe to his Rule, not to admit Strangers without Letters Teſtimonial.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: How ſhould I have Letters Teſtimonial, that have liv'd in an uninhabitable Iſland near the Southern Pole, an Hermetical Life theſe ſixty years.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: But then how did you hear of my fame? There I nick'd the Old Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: We Hermits know all that is done, by Revelation, as well as if we ſaw it with our eyes; How elſe could we endure ſo many years of tedious ſolitude.

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: Nay, Brother, it is certain he might know it by Revelation.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Not improbable, being ſo good a Man.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: I have not ſeen the face of Man or Beaſt theſe Fourſcore years:—Yet I can tell ſome ſecrets of your Life,— Whiſpers Pol. Is not that true?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Moſt certainly true:—Thou art a Divine Perſon.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.p: And when you liv'd alone ſo long in America, Good my Dear Joy, tell me what Company did you uſe to keep?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: My Dog, my Cat, and ſometimes for diverſions ſake, a Monkey.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.p:
And did not you go ſometimes
to ſmoak a Pipe at your Neighbours?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: How could I, when I had none there?

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.p: By my ſhoul, my Dear Joy, I did quite make forget that.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: How long is it ſince you took this Vow to Viſit me?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: About Fifty years.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: That is ſtrange, I am but 40 years old.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: A Pox on his gravity, it made me miſtake his Age. To Pol. O Sir, I knew how Great you would be, long before your Conception.

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: By ſpecial Revelation?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Yes, by ſpecial Revelation.

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: I'll be Hang'd if this Fellow does not come to Beg, to Cheat, or Steal.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Well, it is joyful news to me, that my poor endeavours do meet with that encouragement in the remoter parts of the World: for let me die, if ſome are not ſo bruitiſh here, as to cenſure me for an Hairbrain'd, Imprudent Stateſman.—

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: They are more ſtupid than the meaneſt Animals in our Parts; for the very Parrots are taught to ſay, Wiſe Pol, Prudent Pol, A Cup of Sack for Pol.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: It is the nature of the Engliſh to deſpiſe all Political Wiſdom, becauſe it is a Foreign Commodity: But I perceive the Americans have better Judgment.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Oh! abundantly.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Have you other buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: What greater buſineſs than to ſee your Wiſdom?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Since that's your end, I'll make you ſenſible Fame's no Liar.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Yes, I have one requeſt more, which I hope to obtain by the interceſſion of theſe worthy Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: Give it a Name, and you ſhall ſee our readineſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: The Inhabitants of thoſe Parts, as I partly underſtand it by Revelation, and partly was told in the Ship, are troubled with a Giddineſs in the Head, and other Diſtempers of the Brain, from which they think they can never be delivered, but by the Application of ſomething taken from your body; which I therefore humbly beg you would beſtow upon me, for it will be extreamly reverenced in thoſe Parts.

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: A moſt Pious requeſt; It muſt not be denied.

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: I told you this Fellow came to beg.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: What is it they would have?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: A Glove, a Nightcap, or a pair of Shooes.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: My Man ſhall deliver you the beſt pair I have.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: No: I had rather have a pair your Reverence had worn longeſt; there is likely to be moſt Virtue in them.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I don't believe it can do them any good; but yet the Vulgar are to be indulg'd and gratified in ſuch deſigns, right or wrong.
You ſhall have what ever you will of that nature.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Then be pleaſed to Honour your Humble Servant with an old Handkerchief; for the people of thoſe parts have a great Veneration for all Effluviums of your Brain.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.p: By my ſhoul, my Dear Joy, I have two or three pair of old Shooes, if they will do thy Countrymen any good, they ſhall have them with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: But firſt let's know your Name?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: I was born in England of the Family of the Subtlemans; but when I took upon me the Hermetical Life, I chang'd my Name to Sancto Hermolto de Fulgoſo, alias, The Simple Hermit.

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: Why the Simple Hermit?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: I was proud of that Name, becauſe it ſhew'd my Humility.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Then you were proud of being humble.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Yes, I was very proud of being ſo very humble.—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Mr. Bigot, you know your buſineſs, I will give Orders for the entertainment of this Hermit, and then repair to Leucaſia's Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: I know it, and will execute your Orders with all imaginable diligence and fidelity.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: What doſt thou ſay, Is Sir George Murther'd.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: So it is conjectur'd; and his Man does confidently reports it.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: It cannot be,—they dare not be ſuch Villains.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: It ſeems they dare; the thing is done, and thought to be contriv'd by Father Politico.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: A Man might as well expect to ſee a Mine above Ground, as a deep Plot come from the ſhallow Head of Politico; If he is Author of this barbarous Murther, I dare pawn my reputation, I diſcover it in leſs than half an hours Converſation.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: But you hazard your perſon, in truſting your ſelf in the Houſe with one who would have us'd you ſo ill.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: I hope to find an opportunity to uſe him worſe: Do you obſerve your cue, and leave the reſt to me.
sp.stage: They are going out, but met by Turnabout.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: I'gad Madam, you are very happily met; Did you appoint me this place, or did I appoint you?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: If it had been by your appointment, I ſhould not have been here; but if it had been by mine, it had been likely to ſucceed better: If you fancy any happineſs to your ſelf in this Meeting, it muſt be aſcribed to chance, and not to conduct.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: I am like a good Gameſter that throw'd well ſo often, that the ignorant think he has a great deal of good luck, when it really is a great deal of good skill. I am verily perſuaded that either you or I did contrive this, tho I don't know when or where.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: I have one reaſon to make me think it is yours, becauſe it is to no purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: If it is to no purpoſe, it is you, Lady, that make it ſo: I am ready on my part to make it effectual to all intents and purpoſes whatever.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: If I make it ſo, I will withdraw, and leave you to your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: If you withdraw, you ſpoil all, I can do nothing without your aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Suppoſe I ſhould give you my aſſiſtance, what then?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Then I would renounce the Devil and all his works, ſend for a Parſon, and Marry you immediately.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: That is as much as to ſay, That if the work were done to your hands, you would do it with a great deal of eaſe;—But I am not for that lazy way—you muſt give me ſome proof of your diligence.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Diligence before Matrimony, is like a rich Feaſt before an Appetite, it may be good, but not ſeaſonable: To weary me out with Diligence now, is like riding an Horſe to death before he begins his Journey.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: And how ſhould I know that an Horſe can perform his Journey, unleſs I try him firſt?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, you may try me firſt if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: I have tried you, and find you like the reſt of your Sex, great in promiſes, and little in performance: Did not you promiſe to compleat a revenge upon Politico?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Look you, Madam, I love miſchief, but I hate to do it gratis; upon aſſurance of your love, I will not only ſacrifice that Calf to your incenſed Anger; but Mackdonnel himſelf, with an whole Hecatomb of Iriſh Bulls and Blunders.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: I came hither to learn ſome intelligence of Sir George Subtleman's Death; Will you perform that Office for me, and diſcover the Author of that Villany?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Hang Villany, Death and Murther, It is your Eyes that have Murthered me, and I am glad that I have the opportunity to diſcover that: What do I care for the death of an Old Man, that made no conſcience of living Eighty years? propound any other task, and I'll perform it, tho' difficult enough to puzzle the Devil.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Then bring me a Writing ſubſcrib'd with Politico's own hand, wherein he ſhall acknowledge himſelf to be no Politician, but a Pedant, a Sot, and an Aſs; and in requital, you ſhall have of me whatever you will pleaſe to ask.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: How! make Politico confeſs that!

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Yes, make Politico confeſs that, or ne're ſee my face more. I find Politico is lazy.—I'll to my Coach.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, now you cannot ſtir from this houſe; it is beſet by an unruly Rabble; you muſt endure the fortune of the Siege.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Heavens defend us! what ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: I'll conduct you to a private Apartment, where you may remain without diſcovery; if danger comes near you, I will loſe my Life in your Defence.—Remain there, and I will bring a Subſcription from Politico.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: There is nothing I expect leſs, or deſire more,—Do that, and be as happy as I can make you.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: A happy Match! I told you our meeting would be to the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, the Rabble here already! I bid Bigot not bring them hither this halfhour.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: They are now unruly, Bigot can perſuade them to nothing; they threaten to burn your Houſe down.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Then I can't go to Leucaſia.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Not without danger of your Life.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Why, then my whole Plot is ſpoil'd—To ſee the Malignity of Fortune! Where is Mr. Turnabout and Subtleman?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: They are both in the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: That's well—Engage Mr Turnabout as far as you can in the danger, and leave him in it; Let Mackdonnel command the Servants, and make a vigorous defence, he is apprehenſive of few things, perhaps he will not be apprehenſive of danger. Prepare the Dark Vault for my reception, where, I think it is impoſſible for the many-headed Beaſt, with all its eyes, to find me.—Send the old Hermit to me; but let him know nothing of this diſappointment, it will leſſen my reputation extremely with the Americans.—If the Rabble break in, let them take Father Cautious's Trunk for a Prey, and ſo I may ſave my own; which is good modern Policy.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I ſhall punctually obſerve your Orders.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I am not a little fearful of this danger; but Sancto Hermoldo de Fulgoſo muſt not perceive it.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Reverend Father, how fare you? Have you read over the Notes and Obſervations?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Yes, I have read them.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: And do they pleaſe you?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: I wonder your Reverence will condeſcend to ask that queſtion.—Am I a competent Judge of thoſe Divine Writings?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: But is not the Contrivance wonderful?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Beyond expreſſion or imitation. When I come to tell theſe things to the Americans, they will think I am a Lyar.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I will aſſure you, I have thought upon a Thouſand things more improbable.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: If your Reverence did not affirm it, I could never believe it.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Why look you, Sir, my conſtant method is to compaſs my ends by ſuch means as ſeem moſt contrary.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: So I perceive, with great admiration.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: To that purpoſe, I have ſent one to excite the Rabble to Inſurrection and Sedition againſt us, on purpoſe to further our Cauſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: But how can that be?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Why thus: In the firſt place, the Engliſh Hereticks ſtand much in vindication of their own Innocence: but by this means we ſhall have plenty of Accuſations againſt them.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Is that all?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: No; by theſe means we ſhall render their Subjection more intolerable: for the oftner any Body of Men is ſubdu'd, ſo much heavier is the Yoke the Conquerour impoſes.—There's another.—

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Bleſs me, ſure there can be no more.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I perceive you want the Politicians Perſpective. For in the third place, we ſhall have the pleaſure to ſee the Hereticks make wry Faces under the Whipping-poſts and Gallows, which to me is as Comical a Sigth, as the Poſture-maſter, and all his Motions.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Oh! wonderful! you muſt give me leave to write this down.
sp.stage: Pulls out a Book, and writes.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Well, the buſineſs is done.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: What buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: My Father is diſpatch'd.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Phy! never talk of that.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: It is certainly true.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Where's the Eſtate?

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Secure to my ſelf; the Will made to Leucaſia is loſt.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Then you will give it to the Church.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Becauſe we have done it for you.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Have you done it then?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I will not anſwer directly, but you know what the Caſuiſts ſaid.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: But I would know how, and where you did it.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Thoſe are Secrets, 'tis enough that 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: I dare ſay no more about it; that Old Gentleman will over-hear us.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: He may without danger; he is our deareſt Friend and Confident, come from America to ſee me.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Then I may diſcourſe the buſineſs before him.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: By all means; I would not for 1000 l. that he ſhould be ignorant of our Succeſs. To Sir Geo. Look you here, Father, is new matters of wonder. A young Gentlemen was troubled with an Old Peeviſh Heretical Father, that kept him from a good Eſtate, and would not ſuffer him to turn Catholick; but we have diſpatched him for his Pains, without more noiſe and trouble.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Moſt excellently done.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: I muſt confeſs my ſelf oblig'd to this Gentleman for that kindneſs. But, pray let me know by what means you did it?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Trouble not your head with that; is not the work done?

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Yes, to my great Satisfaction; but ſtill I would know to whom I am moſt oblig'd.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Is any thing of moment done without me?—I muſt take the honour of it upon my ſelf, tho I know nothing of it.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: I believe not, but ſtill it is done with that dexterity, that methinks I would fain learn it.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: That is an height that every Capacity cannot reach.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: And do not you find your heart leap for Joy? Are not you a little tranſported now the work is done?

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: O! beyond meaſure! 'Tis the fineſt thing in the World to jump into an Eſtate, without expecting the tedious Courſe of Nature, that ſeldom gives us variety of Food, before ſhe has pall'd the Appetite.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Well, I perceive now thou art a Villain.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: But you muſt remember half that Eſtate is due to the Church.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: It is all at your Service, if you will but tell me how it was done.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I muſt not diſcover that;—but if you will follow me in, I will ſhew you a Scheme how ſomething may be done that is like it.—Adieu.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: There is nothing I deſire more.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Well, I am now ſatisfied, that my Son is a Rogue and Villain. aſide.—To his Son. Meet me in the great Hall, a quarter of an hour hence, and I will diſcover all.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Was you then an Actor in it.

sp.speaker: Sir. Geo.
sp.p: Yes, a principal one.—Do not fail.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: By no means.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Solus.—So, now my buſineſs is done: I will get a Warrant and Indict them all of Wilful Murther, ſpend the Eſtate merrily, and leave the Fathers in the lurch to be hang'd and damn'd for me.
The Scene changes to a great Hall, where Mack. Turn. Man. Cautions, are diſcover'd ſitting round a Table, on which are ſpread Guns, and Arms of all ſorts.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Look ye Gentlemen, the buſineſs about which we meet, and are to conſult about, is this, whether we are able to reſiſt the Violence of the Rabble; or whether it be beſt to come to an honourable Compoſition?

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: I am for Compoſition, if it can be done without Charges.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.p: And I by my Shoul, I am for Fighting, if it can be done without danger.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: My Maſter commits his ſafety to your care. As you diſcharge that truſt, you may expect his favour.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: If you think of Fighting, we muſt know our number of Arms, Men, and Proviſion.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: As for Proviſions, we have good ſtore of Ale, Beer, French Wine, Brandy, and Uſquebaugh.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: All this is good; and what Servants?

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.p: We have nine Iriſh Foot-men; but thoſe, my dear Joy, are all run away.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And three French Valets; but one has not comb'd his Wig; another has not waſh'd his Face; and a third is puzzled to ſet his Crevat-ſtring; ſo that they cannot be in a Poſture of Defence this hour.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: And is that all?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No, we have two High-German Porters, but they have drunk ſo much to raiſe their Courage, that they have thrown their bulky Bodies, and lye wallowing in the Cellar. We had too an Engliſh Groom and Skullion, but they prove perfidious, and are gone over to the Enemy.

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: And where is my man Jonathan?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: At the head of the Rabble, exciting them to all manner of Indignities.

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: O! miſerable Wretch! I am undone then for ever.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Well, it is no matter for great numbers of Men, what Arms have you? The Rabble are like Jack-Daws, they make an hideous noiſe when they ſpy Carrion, but will fly at the ſmell of a little Gunpowder.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.p: O! by my Shoul! Iſh have the very beſt Guns in the World, but I have forgot to provide one thing.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Pray, what's that?

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.p: A very ſmall thing, 'tis not worth mentioning.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Pray, let's hear it.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.p: By my Shoul, I have forgot to provide a little Gunpowder.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Nay, then we muſt yield. My Opinion, in ſhort, is, that the Place is not Tenable, we muſt Surrender upon Diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And leave my Maſter to have his Brains knock'd out.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Perhaps not.—Go you, and convey him to his dark Vault; then let every Man hide himſelf as conveniently as he can, and leave me, and Mrs. Subtleman, to manage their Fancy. The rage of the People is like the current of a River; let it paſs, and it glides away without damage; but ſtop it, and it overflows all.—What ſay you, Gentlemen, are you agreed?

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: I cannot agree, it is the way to loſe my Trunk.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: We muſt not all periſh for your Trunk.

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: Then I will get into one of my empty Cheſts, and dye, or periſh with them.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.p: And iſh will creep into an Hogſhead, and dye, or periſh with it.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: That will be the firſt thing they'll ſearch for.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.p: Well, I will get under the Bed, and lie in Ambuſh.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: be quick in Execution: I'll go to my Maſter.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.p: Come, Brother Cautious, let us live.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Why, how now Jack, what doſt thou do alone in the midſt of this Confuſion?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Faith Tom, I am contriving a little Miſchief againſt Father Politico, and his Gang, and ſtand in need of thy aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt have it with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: It is no time for words, follow me to the Street-door, and you ſhall ſee it compleated.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Agreed, Love and Revenge move ſwiftly to their end.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Doſt thou ſuſpect, then, Turnabout's Fidelity.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, becauſe he was ſo ready to Surrender.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Ay, but you ſuſpect him againſt the Rules of Policy. For Turnabout has dependencies upon me, Expectancies from me; and it is a general Rule, that ſcarce one Man is true to another, yet every Man is true to his own Intereſt.—Beſides, he hath lately diſoblig'd me, therefore will endeavour to regain my favour.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But what does your Reverence think of Mr. Subtleman?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I think 'tis impoſſible that he ſhould deceive us, wherefore leave them to manage all. Let Sancto Hermolto de Fulgoſo be put into the ſecureſt place of all the Houſe; if he receive any hurt, 'twill leſſen my Reputation in America; let Turnabout and Subtleman keep the Key of the Vault, and none have admittance to me but them; ſecure all my Political Notes and Obſervations, tho the Vulgar may not perceive they are taken from Play-books; remove Hobbs and Machiavel out of my Study, they are ſo thumb'd, it will be a ſhame to ſee them; hide the Pictures of thoſe pretty Ladies Mrs. Counterfeit ſent me: The Rabble will miſtake them for Saints, and burn them: As for the Religious Pictures, it is good to leave them to divert the ſway of the Mobile from things of greater Value.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I ſhall obſerve it.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Turnabout has lately diſoblig'd me, tho againſt his will; and if thou couldſt contrive it ſo, as to excite the Rabble to kick, beat, or toſs him in a Blanket, I ſhould applaud and reward the Action.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: If I durſt appear, I could quickly do it.
sp.stage: Turnabout croſſes the Stage without Hat, Crevat, or Sword.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Mr. Turnabout, your moſt Faithful, Humble, and Obedient Servant.—I ſee you are taking as much pains for my Preſervation, as I take for your Advancement.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: I have no reaſon to doubt it.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: But why in this diſguiſe?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: He that will deal with the Rabble, muſt appear a little like them.—Good Sir, retire with all ſpeed.—I am juſt going to let them in, and can't ſtay to give you a particular Account.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Well, thou art a very fool, and ſo farewell.
sp.stage: Enter Turnabout and John Simper, heading the Rabble.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: You ſee Gentlemen, ye are admitted without Reſiſtance.—Pray, what is your buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: We came to ſearch for Politico.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: I am ſorry he is fled; I got into the Houſe before you on purpoſe to ſurpriſe him, but he and all his Family are vaniſhed.—The Lord.—

sp.speaker: 1 Fellow.
sp.p: Nay, it is probable he did deal with the Devil.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: We came likewiſe to ſearch for Proteſtant Bridles, Popiſh Knives and Trinkets. Bear back there, and let four only Enter.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: The Bridles are in the Stable, the Knives in the Kitchen, and the Trinkets are Relicks, and pack'd up in three or four great Trunks, and thruſt into a Vault in the Cellar.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Let two go and fetch them Exeunt two Porters to fetch them—The Treaſure is in the two little Boxes, ſend them to Wapping, and bring up the other.—Pray Gentlemen, let us proceed with Moderation, no Filching, Stealing, Swearing, or Fighting; let us deſtroy nothing but Popiſh Trinkets.

sp.speaker: 1 Fell.
sp.p: Our Captain ſpeaks very diſcreetly, and we will obey him.

sp.speaker: 2 Fell.
sp.p: Honourable Captain, there is a Controverſy in the Cellar, whether Clarret or Whitewine are not Popiſh Goods, and ought to be deſtroy'd?

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: No queſtion of it. You know the Hugonots are all forbid it in France.

sp.speaker: 1 Fell.
sp.p: I am glad to hear it.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Clear the Houſe of all Maſs-books, and Pictures of Saints.

sp.speaker: 2 Fell.
sp.p: That's quickly done, we have burnt St. Herculus already.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Make diligent ſearch for Politico, or any of his Gang.

sp.speaker: 1 Fell.
sp.p: Dog, Rogue, creep under the Bed! thou art an Iriſh Papiſh, and we will kill thee.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.p: By my Shoul, my dear Joy, I am no Iriſh man, iſh was born at Cork.

sp.speaker: 2 Fell.
sp.p: That Cork ſhant ſtop our Mouth.—Thou art an Iriſh-man, and we will knock thy Brains out.

sp.speaker: 3 Fell.
sp.p: If thou waſt born at Cork, thou muſt needs be light of Foot, and for the Jeſts ſake, I will throw thee out at th' Window.

sp.speaker: 1 Fell.
sp.p: Nay, if he was born at Cork, he muſt needs Swim; we will tye a Stone about's Neck, and throw him into the River, and that's better Jeſt.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.p: Nay, good my dear Joys, do not tie a Stone about my Neck.—I am very tender of my Head, and ſhall catch Cold immediately.

sp.speaker: 2 Fell.
sp.p: I tell thee, mine is the beſt Jeſt.

sp.speaker: 1 Fell.
sp.p: I ſay mine is.
sp.stage: They pull Mackdonnel about, and at laſt fall a Fighting.

sp.speaker: 3 Fell.
sp.p: I ſay mine is.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.p: Nay, when the Hereticks do Fight amongſt themſelves, the good Catholick always make their eſcape.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Pray Gentlemen leave Fighting, and mind your buſineſs. Look, here is an whole Trunk of Popiſh Trinkets.— Enter Porters, and ſet down the Trunk.—Break it open, it belongs to Father Cautious They break it open. ſo in the firſt place here is an old pair of Breeches:—See with what care they are preſerv'd, tho there be a thouſand Holes in them.—Theſe did belong to Mathuſalem.

sp.speaker: 1 Fell.
sp.p: If they did, they ſhall be burnt for Popiſh.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Then here are ſix Shirts.

sp.speaker: 2 Fell.
sp.p: They are not Shirts, but Surplices.—They muſt be burnt too.

sp.speaker: 1 Fell.
sp.p: But what's this wrap'd up in a Paper.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Hang me, if this covetous Dog, Cautious, is not tranſporting the Carcaſs of a Gooſe to France.

sp.speaker: 2 Fell.
sp.p: Pray, Noble Captain, what is it?

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: It is the Body of that famous Conſtantinopolitan Cock, that was raiſed from the dead.

sp.speaker: 1 Fell.
sp.p: Then it was a Popiſh Cock, and we will burn it.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I deſire you to conſult your own ſafety; The Soldiers are marching down with Powder and Ball:—You have ſeen all in the Houſe you can.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: What ſay ye, ſhall we march away?
Rabble, Away, away, away; burn 'em, burn 'em, away, away.—
sp.stage: Exeunt, carrying with them Father Cautious's Trunk.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: So, 'tis well, they are gone,—Mr. Subtleman come out.
Come, Jack, the Coaſt is clear; The Rabble are haſtning away with all expedition; and all Politico's Servants lye ſecure in holes, from whence they dare not ſtir till I call 'em.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Then now is the time to work Politico to your end—Have you plac'd Leucaſia's Footmen in a Room next to Politico's.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Yes, I have given good ſtore of Claret to carrouſe; I taught them a Song that will frighten Politico out of the Vault.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Then let us make haſte and free Leucaſia from all apprehenſion of danger; She is melancholly in the little Parlour: Beſides, I have ſome buſineſs with Mrs. Betty.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: As quick as thou wouldſt have it—My Love moves ſo faſt, I fancy it near the center.
The Scene Draws, and diſcovers Politico lying on a Couch, in a Dark Vault in a Melancholly Poſture.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Well, this laſt Plot of raiſing the Rabble, is likely to prove dangerous, tho' it wants nothing but ſucceſs to render it a Maſterpiece for the beſt Politician in Europe.
sp.stage: A noiſe of Singing and Huzzaing behind the Scenes.
sp.p: But what noiſe is this! O'my Conſcience the Rabble are got into the next Room, I ſhall be torn in pieces before ſuccours can come.

div.stage: A Song behind the Scenes, ſuppos'd to be Sung by the Rabble.

l.hi: COme Brother let's Drink, what ever you think,

lg.l: Politico's Noddle is empty:

l.hi: We'll knock out his Brains, in the Skull that remains
We'll drink Sack and Claret in plenty.
His Fleſh we will eat, it is excellent Meat,
His Blood ſhall ſerve us for Drinking;
His Bones we will pair, till they are ſo bare,
There ſhall be no danger of Stinking.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Bloody Rogues! Villains! they make me tremble, but I ſhall ſhortly have the pleaſure to ſee them all hang'd.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: 'Tis I.—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: You are welcome, but ſpeak ſoftly; what News?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: All's loſt.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: It is not.—I have prudence enough left to recover all.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: I mean all but your Reverence's Prudence.

sp.speaker: Pol
sp.p: But, prethee, what's the matter?—Speak ſoftly.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Captain Tom is fully reſolv'd.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: To do what?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: To ſhut up the Doors, and burn the Houſe down.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Does he know that I am in it?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: As well as I do.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Who betray'd me?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: 'Tis uncertain; he has the beſt Intelligence in Europe; nothing that is done can eſcape his knowledg.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I thought he had been an Ignorant Mechanical Fellow.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: So the World thinks him; but 'tis certain, (excepting your ſelf) he is the greateſt Stateſman in Europe.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: What then would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Reſolve to periſh nobly in the Flames; your Fame will ſhine the brighter.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Burning is no fit Death for a Stateſman, they ſhould dye by Poyſon, or the Ax, or the Halter. Burning puts me in mind of a Smithfield Heretick.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: There is no Ax to be got, but if your Reverence is in very urgent neceſſity, I have a ſmall quantity of Arſenick in one Pocket, and an Halter in the other.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: But why ſo deſperate Mr. Turnabout? Can you bring him to no Conditions?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: None but what are worſe than Death. You can never endure to hear them.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I perceive you don't underſtand the true Rules of Policy. Let the Conditions be never ſo bad, we will hearken to them, give Hopes Accommodation, and interpoſe Delays till Succour come, and he's taken napping.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, that is too vulgar a Policy to impoſe upon a Man of his underſtanding. He will allow you a quarter of an hours time for Deliberation.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Then, pray, let me hear his Conditions.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Firſt, he will have an Inſtrument under your Hand and Seal, wherein you muſt Renounce and Diſclaim all pretences to the Name of a Politician, and acknowledg your ſelf to be a Pedant, an Aſs, and a Fool.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Renounce all Pretences to the Name of Politician, &c. A pretty homour this, I will ſooner dye than do it.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: I will go and tell him ſo.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: No, ſtay, Self-preſervation is a Fundamental Law of Nature. I will ſubmit to it; but why ſhould he impoſe ſuch an unreaſonable Task upon me?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: He is a Rival of your Fame, and envious of your Glory, which he would fain fully, by rendring you Ridiculous in all the Courts in Chriſtendom.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I believe ſo,—and therefore I will ſooner dye than loſe my Honour.—Bid him fire the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: It ſhall be done in a moment.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: But ſtay, pauſes neceſſity has no Law; I muſt ſubmit, tho I had rather loſe ten of my Toes, and ſix of my Fingers. But what is his two Articles.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p:
It is of near Kin to the other.—You muſt ſolemnly Promiſe and Swear, never to intermeddle with Matters of State,
or Haunt the Courts of Princes, or belye the Favours of Great Men, but ſpend the remainder of your time in Study and Devotion.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: It is an impoſſible Condition, I can never perform it.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Becauſe it is as natural to me to intermeddle with Affairs of State, as 'tis to a Bird to fly, or a Fiſh to ſwim. And how ſhould I give up my ſelf to the Study of Books, or Devotion, who have been diſus'd from both theſe twenty years.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: But I ſay it is not impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: But I ſay it is:—Let him burn the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: I ſay it is not; for tho it be impoſſible to perform, yet it is not impoſſible to promiſe.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Ay, there you diſtinguiſh rightly. It is not impoſſible for me to promiſe it.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Then I ſhall tell him that you conſent to his Conditions of Peace.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Yes, do; let him inſult at preſent. I ſhall ſoon over-reach his Policy, and bring him to the Gallows, and then I will ſo diſappoint him of his Fame, that I will not ſo much as ſuffer a Ballad to be made in his Commendation.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: That will vex him extreamly.—I'll return preſently with a Copy of the Agreement.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I'll attend you, but make haſte.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Ne're fear it.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: This Turnabout is a very Gooſe.—I hate him mortally, and yet he thinks me his greateſt Friend.
sp.stage: Enter Turnabout with four of Leucaſia's Footmen.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Here, you Rogues, lies Politico, fright him to ſome purpoſe, but offer no Violence to his Perſon.

sp.speaker: 1 Foot.
sp.p: Let us alone for that.

sp.speaker: 2 Foot.
sp.p: Zooks, Jack, I'll be hang'd if Politico is not hid in this dark Cellar. Let's fetch a Light.

sp.speaker: 3 Foot.
sp.p: Damn a Light, we will grope him out with our Hands.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Now Heavens defend me, Turnabout has left the Door open, and I ſhall fall into the Hands of the Rabble.

sp.speaker: 4 Foot.
sp.p: Groping is the beſt way, but haſt got a Knife ready?

sp.speaker: 2 Foot.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: 4 Foot.
sp.p: To cut out the Dogs Tongue, and keep the tip in our Pockets.

sp.speaker: 2 Foot.
sp.p: I have a Ropes end, and a Bulls Pizzle.

sp.speaker: 3 Foot.
sp.p: They are too gentle Inſtruments. would I have him Broil'd on a Gridiron.

sp.speaker: 4 Foot.
sp.p: I ſay, Boil him in a Caldron.

sp.speaker: 1 Foot.
sp.p: I ſay, Roaſt him.

sp.speaker: 2 Foot.
sp.p: I ſay, 'Igad, lets eat him, if the Rogue does not Stink for fear; he will be good fat Meat.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Bloody Rogues! Villains! What would I give to be free from this danger?

sp.speaker: 3 Foot.
sp.p: The beſt way to catch him, is to ſpread our ſelves over the Room,—and if ye hear him ſtir.—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Oh! But we Politicians have a trick for that.
sp.stage: They grope up and down the Room. Politico pulls off his Shooes, and ſtill as they come near him, ſlips away.

sp.speaker: 2 Foot.
sp.p: Haſt found him Tom?

sp.speaker: 3 Foot.
sp.p: No, but methinks I ſcent him.

sp.speaker: 4 Foot.
sp.p: And 'Igad, I have found his Shooes.

sp.speaker: 1 Foot.
sp.p: Then he muſt be near.

sp.speaker: 2 Foot.
sp.p: We had beſt fetch a Light. All, a Light! a Light! a Light!

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I am glad the Villains are gone; but if they return with a Light before Turnabout brings Articles of Peace, I am undone.—To ſave my Life, I will ſign any Condition, but keep none, becauſe they are extorted, Meta Mortis.
sp.stage: Enter Turnabout with a dark Lanthorn, and Papers in his Hand.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Sir, where are you?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Here, ſweet Mr. Turnabout; you did ill to leave the Door open, the Rabble had almoſt found me: I muſt now be contented to Seal a Blank.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: No, you ſhall not do it: The Inſolence of Captain Tom is intollerable, he will have you not only Sign, but make the ſame acknowledgment before him blindfold.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: And why blindfold, prithee?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: The ambitious Stateſman looks upon that as an acknowledgment, that you are ſo much his Inferior, that you are unworthy to look upon him.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I can never do it. You muſt bid him fire the Houſe, and yet Life is ſweet.—Well, proceed.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: And not only ſo, but he will have you renounce all Pretenſions to Leucaſia, and publickly profeſs, that you believe her to be Miſtriſs of neither Wit, Beauty, or Virtue.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: And why ſo?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: 'Tis Envy, Igad, meer Envy.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Right Mr. Turnabout, it is Envy. I have always obſerv'd, that the greateſt Stateſmen have been my greateſt Enemies. But how could he know any thing of Leucaſia.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Did not I tell you, that he knew all things?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: So it ſeems by this.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Then in the laſt place, you muſt provide him and his Gang a ſplendid Supper, where your ſelf muſt wait upon him in Perſon, drink a Grace-cup of Reconcilement, and be Friends for ever.—Sure you will never ſubmit to this.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Not ſubmit to it, yes, with all mine heart, Ha, ha, ha, He a Politician, he an Aſs. This one falſe ſtep ſhall be his Ruin.—I faith, Captain Tom, I am glad I have catch'd thee in a Trap.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: But how?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Why, look you Mr. Turnabout, this young Man in his laſt Demands, is guilty of two notorious Errors. For 1ſt. He permits his mortal Enemy to fill him Wine at Supper, not conſidering how eaſy a matter 'twere for me to mingle him a glaſs of Arſenick.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Ay, there I proteſt you catch him.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Then by ſtaying Supper, he gives me opportunity to ſend for Guards to ſurpriſe him and his Mermidons; ſee him fairly hang'd, and my ſelf triumphantly ſurvive him; ha, ha. Come, let us make all imaginable haſte to prevent the return of the Rabble.—You ſhall introduce me.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: I attend your Motion.
The Scene changes to a great Hall; Chairs ſet, Leucaſia's Servants attending.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Pleaſe you Madam, to take your Seat, and we will preſent you with the moſt Comical Sight in the World: Mr. Turnabout will preſently be here, and lay the mighty Politico at your Feet, humbly acknowledging himſelf to be a Pedant, an Aſs, and a Fool.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: 'Tis ſo well known, there's no need of his Teſtimony to confirm it; but methinks we ſhould have more Spectators.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: You will ſee enough preſently; I have ſent to Sancto Hermolto de Fulgoſo, Bigot, Cautious, and the whole Gang; we ſhall burſt with Laughter. My Lord Brittain will be here too.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: That Lord is truly Noble, his Native Generoſity too great to be viciated by any Speculative Opinion. I would not have him affronted.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: He will not think himſelf affronted, to ſee a few turbulent Prieſts made Ridiculous. I rather think 'twill give him great Diverſion.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: I could be much Merrier, if I were ſatisfied concerning Sir George's Abſence; and I can aſſure you a great Blemiſh does from thence reflect on you.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, I muſt wipe of that as well as I can; but I am reſolved to be Merry this happy minute, whatever happens the next.—Pray, Madam, take your Seat.
sp.stage: Leucaſia places her ſelf in the great Chair.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Save you Mr. Subtleman, this is an odd Change, to be ſent for out of Danger, to ſee a Play.—I am not us'd to ſuch Diverſion in America.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p:
You will ſee nothing here, but an innocent Repreſentation of ſome Follies of
Human Nature, to diſpel thoſe Melancholly Fumes that are the ſmall Relicks of ſtupifying Dangers.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Nay, you do well to rejoyce. You have loſt a Father.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: I thank the Fates for it, he departed in a very ſeaſonable time.
Aſide to Sir Geo. But are theſe Circumſtances true, that you told me in the Parlour.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: All very true.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: And you, and Politico, Father Cautious, and Bigot, concerned in it.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: All equally concern'd; ſure you'll reward us.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Moſt bountifully.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Aſide. Well, then I do perceive thou art a very Villain.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: My Lord, your very humble Servant, we have prepared a ſmall Interlude, we hope will not be altogether diſpleaſing to your Lordſhip, tho it reflects a little on the Prieſts of your Religion.

sp.speaker: Lord Brit.
sp.p: Never the more for that; I love their Regular, but hate their Excentrick motions; nothing to me is more ridiculouſly Odious.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Then, pray, take your Seat there.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.p: And how my dear Joy, didſt thou come back from Wapping? Or didſt thou ſtay there lock'd up in thy Cheſt till this time?

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: You ſee I am returned, but with an heavy Heart, and a light Purſe. The Rabble carried me thither in one of my own Cheſts, and I lay very ſtill. I underſtood that I was to be clap'd on Board for Sweedland. Then fearing the loſs of my natural Treaſure, I crept away ſlily, and am glad to ſee the Storm is blown over.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.p: Yeſh, by my Shoul, dear Joy, we ſhall have a rare ſhow, and laugh at the Heretical Dogs, till we do make them cry their Eyes out.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Mr. Cautious, why ſo Penſive?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, I have cauſe enough, my Money is all loſt. I ſaw it ſet ſail for Sweedland with a fair Wind, and ſent two or three Sighs after it, which blew it farther from me.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: It is well you are not covetous, if you were, you would hang your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: No, I am not Covetous. But I think your Note did make ſome mention of Money.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: If you had any hand in the Death of the Old Man, I deſign 500 l. for your Reward.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: That is ſome comfort, I could find in my heart to own it.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Well, what ſay you?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I ſay you are greatly beholden to me for it. How, want of Money will make a Man lye!

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Then take your Seat. As ſoon as our Play is done, we'll diſcourſe further about it.
sp.stage: Enter Turnabout leading Politico blinded with an Handkerchief.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: There ſits the Captain, kneel down as ſoon as I give the Sign, and repeat your Leſſon, Totidem Verbis.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I warrant you; but what Company is here?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: None but a confus'd Rabble.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Lead on, I don't value them.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Bleſs me, what is the meaning of that?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I am ſtruck with Admiration!

sp.speaker: Lord Brit.
sp.p: Be ſilent, and attend the iſſue.
sp.stage: Turnabout leads Politico juſt over againſt Leucaſia's Chair, and then ſpeaks ſoftly to him.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Now you are in the right Place • make your Honour.
sp.stage: Politico makes three very low Bows, and then Kneels down.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Softly to Mr. Turnabout.
Methinks tho, Captain Tom might allow me a Cuſhion.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Ne're ſtand upon that, ſpeak out.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Moſt high and mighty, thrice Illuſtrious Hero.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Thrice Illuſtrious is not Title ſufficient. I will be ſtil'd ſix times Illuſtrious Hero.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.p: By my Shoul, my dear Joy, thou art out: Thou muſt ſay half a dozen times Illuſtrious Hero.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Moſt High and Mighty, Six times Illuſtrious Hero.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: That's well.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I do here in the preſence of all this Company—

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Company is too mean a word—I will have egregious Society.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I do here in the preſence of this Egregious Society.

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: Do you know the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Not I: Be ſilent.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Proceed.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Profeſs, own, and declare.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: That is not compleat enough; I will have it profeſs, confeſs, acknowledg, own, declare, denounce, manifeſt, make known and publick.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Softly to Turn. Bleſs me! this Capt. Tom. is very hard to pleaſe—Pray intercede for me to his Highneſs, that there may be ſome abatement.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: 'Tis impoſſible; you muſt perform all.

sp.speaker: Pol.
