sp.p: I do profeſs, confeſs, acknowledg, own, declare, denounce, manifeſt, make known and publick.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: That's tolerably well done.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: To all Chriſtian people, as well Catholicks as others.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: What's that? Speak out.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.p: He doſh ſhay, my dear Joy—To all Chriſtian people, aſh well Infidels aſh others.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: I will paſs that by; Let him proceed.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: That I Politico am no Stateſman, no Wiſe man, no Scholar; but a Pedant, an Aſs, and a Fool.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: That's very right,—I hope, at length you will learn to ſpeak plain truth.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: This Captain Tom has a ſhrill Voice, I fancy he is but an effeminate Fellow.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Tuſh—Proceed, or you will raiſe his fury.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I do alſo Promiſe, Vow, and Swear, That I will not for the future meddle with Affairs of State, or haunt the Courts of Princes, or belye the Favours of Great men; but beſtow the remainder of my time in ſtudy of Books and Learning.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: That's well, ſpeak it out.

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: Is this Politico himſelf! or one that repreſents him?

sp.speaker: L. Brit.
sp.p: I know not, nor do I care; I like things well enough.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: And laſtly, whereas I did pretend admiration of the Lady Leucaſia, I do now Vow, and Declare, that I did but diſſemble, and did never think her Handſome, Witty, Wiſe, or Virtuous.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Ha, ha, The buſineſs is done. Sir, your Servant.
sp.stage: Turnabout pulls off the Handkerchief, The Prieſts grin, and the reſt laugh.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Bleſs me! What is the meaning of this! Here is no Rabble, no Captain Tom, but all Friends, except that pretty Enemy Leucaſia.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: The meaning is, Sir, that you are gull'd, groſly and palpably gull'd;—The Rabble has been gone theſe two hours,—Nothing but your own Fears and Follies has betray'd you into this acknowledgment, by the aſſiſtance of your Humble Servant Turnabout.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: I Vow, Sir, you did ill not to ſtand upon your Guard better; but ſuffer your ſelf to be thus ſurprized by the ſtratagem of a ſilly Woman, and one of your own Pupils.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Rogue—Villain—Dog, haſt thou deceived me?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: 'Tis in vain to fret your ſelf, you taught me to Deceive; your ſelf encourag'd me to Deceive; And how can you be angry that at laſt I have deceived you?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I will be reveng'd for this indignity, To my L. Brittain. My Lord, will you ſuffer one of my Character to be thus abus'd.

sp.speaker: L. Brit.
sp.p:
Sir, I am ready to defend you with my Life, as long as you act in that
Sphere which is proper to your ſtation; but when you exceed the bounds of that, and fall into Calamities and Abſurdities, I muſt leave you.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Alas, my Lord, He can be left in no calamity the ſpace of half an hour;—Let him but take a turn or two about the Room, and he will have Plots enough to confound us all.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Art thou mad, Turnabout, to raiſe up againſt thy ſelf ſo powerful an Enemy?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Not in the leaſt: You are made ridiculous, and your being ridiculous does make you impotent: Nor have you any reaſon to accuſe me of falſhood, ſince I only put in practice the Arts which you taught me.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Confuſion ſeize thee—I will be revenged.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Let him go, he will ſoon be brought again.
sp.stage: Enter Bigot, Speedwell, Counterfeit, and four or five tawdry Whores.

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: The laſt enterprize of ſtirring up the Rabble, did unfortunately miſcarry in my hands: I rais'd 'em with ſucceſs, but could no more Govern the Rogues, than Command a Whirlwind; Inſtead of hurting Leucaſia, they have done infinite damage to our ſelves—But I ſhall recover my credit, by preſenting this goodly Company with ſome new Converts of my own making.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Mr. Bigot, you come too late. But what do you do with all theſe Women?

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: Theſe are Virtuous Ladies, whom I have converted by my own induſtry and eloquence, from their long-imbib'd Errors.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: I perceive a new Scen • e of mirth is opening.

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: Mrs. Speedwell, pray ſpeak for your ſelf; or if you are aſham'd, let me ſpeak for you. To the Company, This Lady, not full two hours ſince, was an inventerate Phanatick, infected with the loathſome Scabs of a Vicious Error.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: What a Spiritual Mountebank this is!

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: But I, by Application of thoſe Remedies that are proper to Diſe • ſ • s of this Nature, have reduc'd her to perfect Internal Sanity. Mrs. Speedwell, pray ſpeak for your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Mr. Subtleman will know me, and then I am diſgrac'd for ever.

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: Be not aſham'd of Truth, it needs no Vizor.
sp.stage: Pulls of her Mask, and ſhews her to Mr. Subtleman.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: O! Mrs. Speedwell, Your very humble Servant—This is a caſt Miſtreſs of mine, ſo damn'd unreaſonable and perfidious, that like the Wars of our French Monarch, She was never to be ſatisfied with Men or Mony.—If this be your new virtuous Convert, I wiſh you much joy of her.

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: Do you jeer me?

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: If I do, it is your fault; you are ſo horridly gull'd in this, that to laugh at you is no matter of choice, but of neceſſity.

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: I ſay, again, Mrs. Speedwell, ſpeak for your ſelf, Is this true?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Why, to ſpeak the truth, a Woman muſt get her livelyhood ſome way or other: I liv'd honeſtly on my Trade, and paid every one till ſtirs and combuſtion came, and my Trade decay'd, and Mr. Subtleman caſt me off; and then I was ſent to turn Religious whether I would or no: And, pray, who can blame me for that?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: A very ingenuous Confeſſion.

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: Well, tho' I am miſtaken in this one, yet Envy it ſelf can object, I preſume, nothing againſt the other—Pray let them declare their moſt ſtupendious Converſion.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: You need not, I know them all—They are a parcel of Jilting Queans, pick'd up from Suburb Bawdy-houſes; the leavings of Porters and Footmen—Pray Mr. Bigot remove them, they are very offenſive.

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: If I thought ſo, I would turn them off, they will be a ſcandal.

sp.speaker: 1 Whore,
sp.p: Ay, but you promis'd me a new Gown.
And me a Place at Court
And me a Penſion.
And me to be Lady Abbeſs.
You told us you would bring us to Court.
And ſaid we ſhould have Dogs, and Monkeys, and live like Ladies.
And that we ſhould take place of all the Hereticks.
And that we ſhould ride in Coaches and Chairs—And now do you think to put us off ſo?

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: But Mr. Turnabout ſays you are Whores—And I will have nothing to do with Whores.
Then I'll ſeize your Crevat for default of payment.
And I your Perruke.
And I your Hat.
And I'll have a Pennyworth out of your Eyes—D'ye think an honeſt Woman can go to Church for nothing?
sp.stage: They all fall upon him, and tear him about.

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: Murther, murther, Help me, or I ſhall be deſtroy'd.

sp.speaker: L. Brit.
sp.p: I am ſick of theſe follies, and will retire.

sp.speaker: Cau. and Her.
sp.p: Hold, Hold,—
sp.stage: They interpoſe, and take 'em off him.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: I proteſt, Mr. Bigot, I can but pity you; you had like to have incurr'd Acteon's fate, and been devour'd by your own Hounds.
sp.stage: Enter Conſtable and Watch, bringing in Politico.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Here Mr. Subtleman, This I ſuppoſe is the Man.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: The very ſame; and I charge you to ſeize this, and this, and this—
sp.stage: Pointing to Cautious, Bigot, and Hermolto.

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: What is this part of your Play!

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: No, Faith I am in earneſt; you muſt all four go before the Juſtice, where I muſt accuſe you of the wilful murther of my Honoured Father, Sir George Subtleman.
sp.stage: Counterfeit and the Whores run away.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: How dare you attempt one of my Figure?

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: I ſhall leave that to the Law, the Judge, and the Hangman—Alas! Sir, I am but a poor Inſtrument in the Proſecution.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: And wilt thou bring theſe Gray Hairs, and this Reverend Beard to the Gallows?

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Faith, Reverend Father, I muſt confeſs there is ſome difficulty in Hanging a Man with ſo long a Beard; but if it be troubleſome to you, you may tye it up under a Cap, or tuck it under your Girdle;—or uſe any other method moſt agreeable to your diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Nay, if you be in earneſt—I proteſt I had no hand in it.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: I can depoſe on Oath, you confeſs'd to me that you had.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: It was cleverly done, and I thought it was for my Reputation.

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: I am Innocent as the Child unborn.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: But you confeſs'd the Fact to me.

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: That was to recover the loſs of my Trunk.

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: I never did it; but I wiſh I had.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: We have witneſs againſt you, and you ſhall be hang'd for wiſhing. Conſtable do your Office.
sp.stage: Conſtable, &c. offer to drag them away.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Nay, now I am in a fine caſe; if I ſhould come to be hang'd for killing my my ſelf, it were a pretty Jeſt, if it were not too much in earneſt.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: I ſay, Conſtable do your Office.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Nay, then 'tis time to diſcover my ſelf—
sp.stage: Sir George throws off his Diſguiſe, and diſcovers himſelf.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: O! Sir George, Sir George, you are welcome from the Dead.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Yes faith, Gentlemen, I am honeſt old hearty Sir George Subtleman, that took this Diſguiſe, and ſpread abroad the report of my Death, to ſee how far my Son was debauch'd with the Principles of their damn'd Caſuiſtical Divinity; and ſince I find him pretty honeſt, as the times go, I will give him all.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: O, my deareſt Father, How am I ſurpris'd to ſee you!

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: I am tranſported with joy! The turn is ſo wonderful, and it had nto ſpoil'd the Hanging of theſe Sacerdotal Vermin, nothing could have hapned more delightful.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: How damnably am I deceiv'd! I told the whole Court he came from America.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: We are all diſpos'd for mirth but theſe Gownmen, who have moſt reaſon, as having eſcap'd the greateſt danger.

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: Since I have loſt my Trunk, Hanging could be no great affliction.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: When I have loſt my Reputation, what does my Life ſignifie?

sp.speaker: Big.
sp.p: I ſee the Catholick Cauſe is dying, I wiſh that I could dye with it.

sp.speaker: Turn. to Leu.
sp.p: Madam, I have now perform'd my Promiſe, and expect you to give me my Reward, without fraud or Jeſuitical equivocation.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Here, take my Hand, and Aſſurance with it, That from this time I ſhall be always yours; I did always Love you, tho' ſome Courſes you took did highly diſoblige me, from which I was reſolv'd to reclaim you. But your laſt good ſervice has cancell'd all former miſcarriages; and ſince you have given me this half hour of pleaſure, I ſhall dedicate the remainder of my Life and Fortune to make you happy.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: And faith, Madam, ſince you are ſo bountiful, I ſhall leave all this crew of whimſical Pedants, and the damn'd Vices of this Town, and ſtudy only how to make my ſelf happy by pleaſing you.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: I faith Neece, this is to the purpoſe, I will be merry at your Wedding, and Dance, and Jump, and Sing, and Hollow; and for Mr. Turnabout's encouragement, will ſettle 200 l. per Annum on the firſt Child, and allow my Son ſo competent a maintenance, that he ſhall not need to depend on that Gang any longer.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Then all have reaſon to rejoyce; none but the Fathers are dejected.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: I know they are concern'd for their loſs of Reputation; Politico ſhall give us a Supper, as he promis'd, and Captain Tom and we will conceal all thoſe diſappointments.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Agreed, for Peace ſake I will do it; but you muſt be ſure to be very ſecret, and I will never meddle with buſineſs of this nature more.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Then all is happily ended: For—

lg.l: When Prieſts forſake the buſineſs of the State,
And on the Duties of their Office wait,
Expect the Iſſue of a proſperous fate.
But when they ſteer the Helm, they hurry on
A diſmal Night of black confuſion.
Nature a wound in every part muſt feel,
And her whole ſyſteme with diſorder reel.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p: TO the two Univerſities, an Epiſtle. Together with a Prediction concerning the French; Tranſlated out of Callimachus: Who is, by St. Paul, ſaid to be a Prophet, and that his Teſtimony is true, Titus I. 12, 13.
The Secret Hiſtory of the Dutcheſs of Portſmouth; Giving an account of the Intreagues of the Court during her Miniſtry. And of the Death of K. C. II.
Both Printed for, and Sold by Richard Baldwin, near the Oxford-Arms in Warwick-Lane, 1690.
